Design and Development of Tensile Testing Machine

Project Summary

This project focuses on the design and development of a cost-effective tensile testing machine using SolidWorks, Arduino UNO, and a 3D-printed frame. The machine is built to test the tensile strength of 3D-printed PLA and ABS samples, simulating the basic functionality of commercial UTM machines for academic and research purposes.

Project Description

The tensile testing machine was designed in SolidWorks with a focus on modularity and manufacturability using PLA and ABS materials. The main components include:

  • 5kg Load Cell and HX711 for force sensing
  • Arduino UNO for microcontroller-based control and data acquisition
  • NEMA 17 stepper motor for linear actuation of the tensile fixture
  • 3D printed structural parts and clamps for easy customization

The project also involved programming the Arduino to read data from HX711 and calculating force in real-time, while controlling motor speed for uniform strain application. The resulting stress-strain behavior was validated by plotting the acquired data.

Tools Used

  • SolidWorks (3D modeling)
  • Arduino IDE (firmware and control)
  • HX711 amplifier, Load Cell, NEMA 17 stepper motor
  • Fusion360 for slicing and printing

Skills Gained

  • Mechanical Design and Assembly
  • Embedded Systems Programming
  • Sensor Calibration and Data Acquisition
  • Stress-Strain analysis and testing methodology

Conclusion

The project successfully demonstrated the feasibility of building a desktop tensile testing machine for basic material strength evaluation. The machine is low-cost, customizable, and can be used in academic labs for hands-on materials testing experience.
